body:
ACK on using a sized type here.
However, changing from signed to unsigned is, in principle, a P2P protocol change.
This needs to be carefully reviewed for potential unexpected by-effects.

According to https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Protocol_documentation#Inventory_Vectors (section written in 2010 by "MagicalTux") this is unsigned. Though, our python tests also treat this as signed. https://btcinformation.org/en/developer-reference#inv doesn't say anything about signedness.

Would be good to at least update the python test framework and also add a p2p test.

> Would be good to at least update the python test framework and also add a p2p test.

Updated the python test framework and added test coverage.

diff_hunk:
@@ -125,6 +128,16 @@ def test_msgtype(self):
             conn.sync_with_ping(timeout=1)
         self.nodes[0].disconnect_p2ps()
 
+    def test_inv_msg_with_negative_type(self):
+        self.log.info("Test inv with negative type raises argument out of range error")
+        invalid_inv = msg_inv([CInv(t=-1, h=1)])  # inv type must be an unsigned integer
+        try:
+            self.nodes[0].add_p2p_connection(P2PInterface()).send_message(invalid_inv)
+        except struct.error as e:

body:
```suggestion
        inv_with_signed_type = msg_inv([CInv(t=0xffffffff, h=1)])
```

Serialized -1 as signed integer is identical to 0xffffffff serialized as unsigned integer, so might as well use the latter
diff_hunk:
@@ -125,6 +129,27 @@ def test_msgtype(self):
             conn.sync_with_ping(timeout=1)
         self.nodes[0].disconnect_p2ps()
 
+    def test_inv_msg_with_signed_int_types(self):
+        self.log.info("Test inv with signed `type` raises argument out of range error")
+        inv_with_signed_type = msg_inv([CInv(t=-MSG_TX, h=1)])  # inv type must be an unsigned integer
+        try:
+            self.nodes[0].add_p2p_connection(P2PInterface()).build_message(inv_with_signed_type)
+        except struct.error as e:
+            assert_equal("argument out of range", str(e))
+        else:
+            raise AssertionError("No exception raised")
+
+        # Repeat, passing signed integer CInv type format to override default.
+        LE_signed_int = "<i"  # Python format chars for little-endian signed int
+        inv_with_signed_type = msg_inv([CInv(t=-MSG_TX, h=1, f=LE_signed_int)])

body:
That was breaking this method in `messages.py::CInv` with `KeyError: 4294967295` from calling `CInv::typemap[4294967295]`
```python
    def __repr__(self):
        return "CInv(type=%s hash=%064x)" \
            % (self.typemap[abs(self.type)], self.hash)
```

body:
Travis seem happy. I have the following minor cleanups in mind but will wait for feedback before pushing.
```diff
test/functional/p2p_invalid_messages.py
@@ -142,12 +142,12 @@ class InvalidMessagesTest(BitcoinTestFramework):
         LE_signed_int = "<i"  # Python format chars for little-endian signed int
         inv_with_signed_type = msg_inv([CInv(t=-MSG_TX, h=1, f=LE_signed_int)])
-        with self.nodes[0].assert_debug_log(["got inv: 0xffffffff 00000"]):
+        with self.nodes[0].assert_debug_log(["got inv: 0xffffffff "]):
             self.nodes[0].add_p2p_connection(P2PInterface()).send_message(inv_with_signed_type)
 
         # Sanity check with valid unsigned inv type and same format override.
         inv_with_unsigned_type = msg_inv([CInv(t=MSG_WTX, h=1, f=LE_signed_int)])
-        with self.nodes[0].assert_debug_log(["got inv: wtx 0000"]):
+        with self.nodes[0].assert_debug_log(["got inv: wtx "]):

test/functional/test_framework/messages.py
@@ -251,7 +251,7 @@ class CInv:
     def __init__(self, t=0, h=0, f="<I"):
         self.type = t
         self.hash = h
-        self.inv_type_format = f  # default format is unsigned int
+        self.inv_type_format = f  # default is little endian unsigned int
```

body:
> According to https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Protocol_documentation#Inventory_Vectors (section written in 2010 by "MagicalTux") this is unsigned. Though, our python tests also treat this as signed. https://btcinformation.org/en/developer-reference#inv doesn't say anything about signedness.

btcinformation.org does show this as uint32_t: https://btcinformation.org/en/developer-reference#data-messages. That was added by @harding to the bitcoin.org developer docs here: https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/Bitcoin.org/commit/1634212dd5550bb9b610341668b4b7b5fa3690a5#diff-693f5b3e9d88b97c899694c8d1656cbbR110

Note that even though comparing an int to a uint32_t causes a UBSan warning, it's not actually undefined behaviour: https://clang.llvm.org/docs/UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer.html#:~:text=%2Dfsanitize%3Dimplicit%2Dinteger%2D,the%20new%20value%20is%20negative. However, I think it's still worth changing this, so that we're always comparing / xor'ing a uint32_t with a uint32_t, so concept ACK.

Great links @jnewbery, thanks.

> Note that even though comparing an int to a uint32_t causes a UBSan warning, it's not actually undefined behaviour: [clang.llvm.org/docs/UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer.html#:~:text=%2Dfsanitize%3Dimplicit%2Dinteger%2D,the%20new%20value%20is%20negative](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer.html#:~:text=%2Dfsanitize%3Dimplicit%2Dinteger%2D,the%20new%20value%20is%20negative).

"-fsanitize=implicit-integer-sign-change: Implicit conversion between integer types, if that changes the sign of the value...issues caught by this sanitizer are not undefined behavior, but are often unintentional."

I don't think this `abs()` is correct. There should be no reason to take an absolute value here, convert, say, `-1` to `1`.

maybe
```
self.typemap.get(self.type, "Error")
```
diff_hunk:
@@ -244,27 +244,28 @@ class CInv:
         MSG_TX | MSG_WITNESS_FLAG: "WitnessTx",
         MSG_BLOCK | MSG_WITNESS_FLAG: "WitnessBlock",
         MSG_FILTERED_BLOCK: "filtered Block",
-        4: "CompactBlock",
-        5: "WTX",
+        MSG_CMPCT_BLOCK: "CompactBlock",
+        MSG_WTX: "WTX",
+        0xffffffff: "Error",
     }
 
     def __init__(self, t=0, h=0):
         self.type = t
         self.hash = h
 
     def deserialize(self, f):
-        self.type = struct.unpack("<i", f.read(4))[0]
+        self.type = struct.unpack("<I", f.read(4))[0]
         self.hash = deser_uint256(f)
 
     def serialize(self):
         r = b""
-        r += struct.pack("<i", self.type)
+        r += struct.pack("<I", self.type)
         r += ser_uint256(self.hash)
         return r
 
     def __repr__(self):
         return "CInv(type=%s hash=%064x)" \
-            % (self.typemap[self.type], self.hash)
+            % (self.typemap[abs(self.type)], self.hash)

body: I'm not sure what to do here. This was only needed for the test. I tried a few [different tests](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/6c0f4aefe373bb89188e91464326dabf0f9f3397); the first one doesn't require adding entries to `typemap`. I don't think any of the tests cover the `protocol.{h,cpp} CInv::type` type change, only the test framework change.

body: Thanks everyone for your feedback. I wrote a [few tests](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/6c0f4aefe373bb89188e91464326dabf0f9f3397) but they all covered the change to the CInv class in the test framework, not the CInv change in `protocol.{h,cpp}`, so I've simplified and removed them in the latest push.
Thanks for addressing the comments, the code changes look good to me now.

> All the values we ever assign to CInv::type are non-negative within the reach of a signed 32 bit integer. GetDataMsg is uint32_t and in some places we |= a variable of type uint32_t into CInv::type

Bitwise arithmetic should definitely use unsigned integers, good point.

> Actually serializing a signed integer in the way we do it is not portable, it just works because all platforms use two's complement, but that's not guaranteed.

I thought this was already guaranteed in C++11, but no, apparently only [C++20](http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/docs/papers/2018/p0907r1.html) will guarantee two's complement signed integers.
ACK 407175e0c2bc797599ebd9c0a1f2ec89ad7af136
